title: Michel Chartier
text:
Michel Chartier, (February 26, 1912 – July 11, 2006) is a <a href="France">French</a> <a href="priest">priest</a> and <a href="journalist">journalist</a>.
Biography.
In the 1930s, he was <a href="vicar">vicar</a> in <a href="Givors">Givors</a> . During the <a href="Second%20world%20war">Second World War</a>, he was captured in a <a href="stalag">stalag</a>. Secretary of the priest Joseph Folliet to the <a href="Chronique%20sociale">Chronique sociale</a>
(<a href="Lyon">Lyon</a>), "<a href="Fidei%20donum">Fidei donum</a>" priest of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Lyon">Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lyon</a> in <a href="Senegal">Senegal</a> (late 1950s, early 1960s) and head in <a href="Dakar">Dakar</a> of the <a href="catholic">catholic</a> journals "Afrique Documents" and "La Semaine africaine, "before being <a href="editor-in-chief">editor-in-chief</a> of "Peuples du Monde" and become <a href="librarian">librarian</a> of the <a href="Pontifical%20Mission%20Societies">Pontifical Mission Societies</a> in Lyon. Michel Chartier was one of the outstanding figures of social Catholicism in Lyon of the second half of the 20th century. Besides hundreds of articles and book reviews, he has published, with the <a href="economist">economist</a> Gilbert Blardone, the priest Joseph Folliet and the abbot Henri Vial, the book "Initiation économique et sociale" (Editions of the Chronique Sociale, 1956). He is buried in the municipal cemetery of Boyer.
